factoid: Alpátych stammered "Your… your excellency" and broke into sobs.
Alpátych asked whether they were really lost.
Prince Andrew repeated "Why are you here?".
Flames flared up and showed Alpátych’s young master’s pale worn face.
Alpátych explained that he had been sent there and that it was difficult to get away.
Prince Andrew took out a notebook, raised his knee, and began writing in pencil on a torn page.

Prince Andrew wrote a note to his sister stating that Smolénsk is being abandoned, that Bald Hills will be occupied by the enemy within a week, that she should set off immediately for Moscow, that she should let him know when she will start, and that she should send the note by special messenger to Usvyázh.
Prince Andrew gave the paper to Alpátych and instructed him to arrange departure for the prince, the princess, his son, and the boy’s tutor, and to inform him immediately where and how.
A chief of staff and a suite galloped up to Prince Andrew.
The chief of staff shouted "You are a colonel?" with a German accent.
The chief of staff said that houses are set on fire in Prince Andrew’s presence and that Prince Andrew will answer for it.
Berg, the assistant to the chief of staff of the commander of the left flank of the infantry of the first army, shouted that the place is very agreeable and well evident.
Prince Andrew looked at Berg and continued speaking to Alpátych without replying.

Prince Andrew instructed Alpátych to tell them that he would await a reply until the tenth, and that if by the tenth he did not receive news that they had all got away, he would have to throw up everything and come himself to Bald Hills.
Berg recognized Prince Andrew, said he had to obey orders, and apologized.
Something cracked in the flames, the fire died down for a moment, and wreaths of black smoke rolled from under the roof.
Another terrible crash occurred and something huge collapsed.
The crowd yelled "Ou-rou-rou!" echoing the crash of the collapsing roof of the barn, and the burning grain diffused a cake-like aroma all around.
The flames flared up again, lighting the animated, delighted, exhausted faces of the spectators.
The man in the frieze coat raised his arms and shouted that it was fine, that it was raging, and that it was fine.
Several voices cried that it was the owner himself.
Prince Andrew told Alpátych to report to them as he had told him.
Prince Andrew did not reply to Berg, who was now mute beside him, and rode down the side street.
